data.description: Reboot fails when there is no "kernelopts" option in the grubenv
data.summary: Reboot fails when there is no "kernelopts" option in the grubenv.
data.generic: Reboot fails when there is no **"kernelopts"** option in the grubenv.
data.reason: This host is running RHEL 8 with no **"kernelopts"** option in the `/boot/grub2/grubenv`. GRUB reads **"kernelopts"** option from grubenv file for boot entry **"root="**. If **"kernelopts"** option does not exist, **"root="** cannot get correct value. As a result, the initial boot sequence with initramfs does not mount the root filesystem and fails to start switch root.

data.description: Kernel panic occurs due to a bug in the mitigation part of KVM for L1TF bug fix
data.summary: Kernel panic occurs when the mitigation control for KVM is read or KVM guest is started on a system with L1TF mitigation without EPT support.
data.generic: Kernel panic occurs when the mitigation control for KVM is read or KVM guest is started on a system with L1TF mitigation without EPT support.
data.reason:
This host is running **kernel-{{=pydata.kvra}}** with `kvm_intel` module loaded. The CPU model of this host is **{{=pydata.name}}** and the `EPT` feature {{?!pydata.has_ept}}is not supported on this CPU{{??}}{{?pydata.boot_disabled}}has been disabled{{?}}{{?}}.
Kernel panic can occur due to a bug in the mitigation control of KVM introduced by L1TF bug fix.
data.more_info: For guidance on upgrading the kernel to a specific version, refer to [How do I upgrade the kernel to a particular version manually?](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/161803).

resolution_set.resolution:
Red Hat recommends that you perform the following steps:

{{?pydata.cur_lock && pydata.rcm_locks}}
* Unset the release lock.
  ~~~
  # subscription-manager release --unset
  ~~~
{{?}}

{{?pydata.no_base &&
  (pydata.cur_lock==null || (pydata.cur_lock && pydata.rcm_locks))}}
* Enable the RHEL base repo:
  ~~~
  # subscription-manager repos --enable={{=pydata.no_base}}
  ~~~
  Note: To fix the issue in the base channel, you have to enable the base channel at first.
{{?}}

{{?pydata.cur_lock && pydata.req_repos && pydata.rcm_locks==null}}
* {{?Object.keys(pydata.req_repos).length > 1}}Enable one of the following channels{{??}}Enable the following channel{{?}}:
  ~~~
  {{~pydata.req_repos:e}}# subscription-manager repos --enable={{=e}}
  {{~}}
  ~~~
  Note: Red Hat only provides the resolution in the required channel{{?Object.keys(pydata.req_repos).length > 1}}s{{?}}. 
{{?}}
* Upgrade the kernel to {{?pydata.kvra.indexOf("el7") != -1}}**3.10.0-951.el7**{{?}}{{?pydata.kvra.indexOf("el6") != -1}}**2.6.32-754.6.3.el6**{{?}} or later:
  ~~~
  # yum update kernel
  ~~~
* Reboot the system with the new kernel:
  ~~~
  # reboot
  ~~~

data.description: System panic occurs when NULL pointer dereference occurs in CIFS module due to a bug
data.tags: cifs filesystem kernel panic sbr_storage storage
data.summary: System panic occurs when NULL pointer dereference occurs in CIFS (Common Internet File System) module, due to a bug in kernel.
data.generic: System panic occurs when NULL pointer dereference occurs in CIFS (Common Internet File System) module, due to a bug in kernel.
data.more_info: For guidance on upgrading the kernel to a specific version, refer to [How do I upgrade the kernel to a particular version manually?](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/161803).

resolution_set.resolution:
Red Hat recommends that you upgrade the `kernel` to version **3.10.0-862.14.4.el7** or later and reboot to use the new kernel.
  ~~~
  # yum update kernel
  # reboot
  ~~~

data.description: Decreased security: Unsupported RHEL release
data.summary: This system is not able to get latest package via subscription tool.
data.generic: This system is not able to get latest package via subscription tool.
data.more_info:
* [How to tie a system to a specific update of Red Hat Enterprise Linux? ](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/238533)
* [How to limit updates a specific version of Red Hat Enterprise Linux? ](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/2761031)
* [Red Hat Enterprise Linux Life Cycle, Extended Update Support (EUS), and Extended Life-cycle Support (ELS)](https://access.redhat.com/support/policy/updates/errata/)
* [Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) Extended Update Support (EUS) Overview](https://access.redhat.com/node/721513)
* [yum returns "No Packages marked for Update" message](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/3433671)
* The Customer Portal page for the [Red Hat Security Team](https://access.redhat.com/security/) contains more information about policies, procedures, and alerts for Red Hat Products.
* The Security Team also maintains a frequently updated blog at [securityblog.redhat.com](https://securityblog.redhat.com).

resolution_set.resolution:
{{?pydata.suggested}}
Red Hat recommends that you use a supported RHEL release by unsetting the release lock.

~~~
# subscription-manager release --unset
~~~

**Alternatively**, if unsetting the release lock is not an option, fix this issue by re-setting the release lock to the latest RHEL release:

1. List available releases.
    ~~~
    # subscription-manager release --list
    ~~~
1. Set lock to the latest release, e.g. {{=pydata.suggested}}.
    ~~~
    # subscription-manager release --set={{=pydata.suggested}}
    ~~~

Red Hat recommends that you test the change and review the new settings before applying them to production systems.
{{?? pydata.rhel_version == 6}}Red Hat recommends that you upgrade to a newer version of RHEL or to Extended Life-cycle Support. RHEL {{=pydata.rhel_version}} has no release in Full Support Phase or Maintenance Support Phase.
{{??}}Red Hat recommends that you upgrade to a newer version of RHEL or to Extended Update Support. RHEL {{=pydata.rhel_version}} has no release in Full Support Phase or Maintenance Support Phase.
{{?}}

data.description: When the Insights Client is earlier than "3.1.0", it is not able to get recommendations dependent on core collection
data.summary: The host is not able to get recommendations dependent on core collection.
data.generic: Since the Insights Client version "3.1.0", a new feature named "core collection" is provided. Some new recommendations are dependent on the core collection. So, if Insights Client earlier than "3.1.0" is being used, it is not able to get the recommendations dependent on that new feature.
data.reason: The Insights Client package **{{=pydata.pkg}}** installed on this host is old and the core collection feature is not available in that version. As a result, it is not able to get the recommendations dependent on the core collection.

resolution_set.resolution:
{{?pydata.cur_lock}}
Red Hat recommends that you set **"core_collect=True"** in the `/etc/insights-client/insights-client.conf` file.

Alternatively, since the current release **RHEL {{=pydata.cur_lock}}** set on
this host does not provide the package, there is no direct solution. Red Hat
recommends that you perform the following steps an alternative:
1. Unset the minor release:
  ~~~
  # subscription-manager release --unset
  ~~~
{{?pydata.no_base}}
1. Enable the RHEL base repo:
  ~~~
  # subscription-manager repos --enable={{=pydata.no_base}}
  ~~~
  Note: Red Hat only provides the package in the ``{{=pydata.no_base}}`` channel.
{{?}}{{?pydata.old}}
1. Uninstall the old package
  ~~~
  # yum remove redhat-access-insights
  ~~~
{{?}}
1. {{?pydata.old}}Install{{??}}Update to{{?}} the latest package:
  ~~~
  # yum {{?pydata.old}}install{{??}}update{{?}} insights-client
  ~~~
{{??}}
Red Hat recommends that you perform the following steps:
{{?pydata.no_base}}
* Enable the RHEL base repo:
  ~~~
  # subscription-manager repos --enable={{=pydata.no_base}}
  ~~~
  Note: Red Hat only provides the package in the ``{{=pydata.no_base}}`` channel.
{{?}}{{?pydata.old}}
* Uninstall the old package
  ~~~
  # yum remove redhat-access-insights
  ~~~
{{?}}
* {{?pydata.old}}Install{{??}}Update to{{?}} the latest package:
  ~~~
  # yum {{?pydata.old}}install{{??}}update{{?}} insights-client
  ~~~

{{?pydata.cc_true}}
Alternatively, if updating the package is not allowed, you can set **core_collect=True** in the `/etc/insights-client/insights-client.conf` file.
{{?}}{{?}}

data.description: When the Insights Client set "core_collect=False", it is not able to get recommendations dependent on core collection
data.summary: The host is not able to get recommendations dependent on core collection.
data.generic: Since the Insights Client version "3.1.0", a new feature named "core collection" is provided. Some new recommendations are dependent on the core collection. If "core_collect=False" is set, it is not able to get the recommendations dependent on that new feature.
data.reason: The Insights Client is set not using the core collection. As a result, it is not able to get the recommendations dependent on the core collection.

resolution_set.resolution: Red Hat recommends that you remove the **"core_collect=False"** from the `/etc/insights-client/insights-client.conf`.

data.description: Kernel panic occurs when the qxl driver is being used on the RHEL 8 system due to a bug in the kernel
data.summary: Due to a known bug in the kernel, when the system is using qxl video driver, kernel panic occurs in a kworker executing drm_fb_helper_dirty_work() function because of invalid memory reference access.
data.generic: Due to a known bug in the `kernel`, when the system is using `qxl` video driver, kernel panic occurs in a kworker executing **drm_fb_helper_dirty_work()** function because of invalid memory reference access by **drm_fb_helper_dirty_work()** function. The issue has been observed with the kernel version earlier than **kernel-4.18.0-305.19.1.el8_4** on RHEL 8.
data.reason: This host is running Red Hat Enterprise Linux **{{=pydata.rhel}}** with the **kernel-{{=pydata.affected_kernel}}**. Due to a known bug in the **kernel-{{=pydata.affected_kernel}}**, when the `qxl` driver is loaded and the `bochs_drm` driver is not loaded on the host, kernel panic occurs in a kworker executing  **drm_fb_helper_dirty_work()** function because an invalid memory reference in **memcpy_erms()** function is accessed by **drm_fb_helper_dirty_work()** function. This issue is caused due to insufficient locking during access to the "qxl_bo" structure used internally by `qxl` driver.
data.more_info: For guidance on upgrading the kernel to a specific version, refer to [How do I upgrade the kernel to a particular version manually?](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/161803)

data.description: The mssql-server service will fail to start when the ownership or group of Microsoft SQL Server directory /var/opt/mssql is not correct
data.summary: When the ownership and group of Microsoft SQL Server directory /var/opt/mssql is not "mssql:mssql", the mssql-server service will fail to start.
data.generic: When the ownership and group of Microsoft SQL Server directory `/var/opt/mssql` is not **"mssql:mssql"**, the `mssql-server` service will fail to start.
data.reason:
This host is running as a Microsoft SQL Server with the following incorrect ownership or group of `/var/opt/mssql`:

- Owner: `{{=pydata.ownership_of_var_opt_mssql['owner']}}`
- Group: `{{=pydata.ownership_of_var_opt_mssql['group']}}`

resolution_set.resolution:
Red Hat recommends that you change the ownership and group of `/var/opt/mssql` to **mssql:mssql**:
  ~~~
  # chown -R mssql:mssql /var/opt/mssql
  ~~~

data.description: Microsoft SQL Server is installed on an unsupported Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL)
data.summary: Microsoft SQL Server is installed on an unsupported Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL).
data.generic: Microsoft SQL Server is installed on an unsupported Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL).
data.reason: This host is running as a Microsoft SQL Server with version **{{=pydata.sql_version}}**. The supported versions for Microsoft SQL Server are RHEL 7.3, RHEL 8.0 and later. However, The current host is running on **RHEL{{=pydata.rhel_version}}** which is not a supported version.
data.more_info: For more information about the requirements of Microsoft SQL Server installation on Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL), refer to [Installation guidance for SQL Server on Linux](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/linux/sql-server-linux-setup?view=sqlallproducts-allversions).

resolution_set.resolution:
Red Hat recommends that you complete the following steps:

* Install Microsoft SQL server on a supported RHEL version:
  ~~~
  RHEL 7: 7.3 or later
  RHEL 8: 8.0 or later
  ~~~

data.description: Kernel panic occurs when ip6_route_dev_notify function receives an empty pointer from snmp6_alloc_dev while unregistering IPv6 enabled network device due to a known bug in the kernel
data.summary: Due to a known bug in kernel, kernel panic occurs when ip6_route_dev_notify function receives an empty pointer from snmp6_alloc_dev while unregistering IPv6 enabled network device.
data.generic: Kernel panic occurs when `ip6_route_dev_notify` function receives an empty pointer from `snmp6_alloc_dev` while unregistering IPv6 enabled network device, due to a known bug in the `kernel`. This is a **regression** introduced in the `kernel` version **kernel-3.10.0-693.el7** and fixed in **kernel-3.10.0-957.el7**.
data.reason:
This host is running **kernel-{{=pydata.kernel}}** and {{?Object.keys(pydata.ipv6_dev_routes).length>1}}`IPv6` routes are added for IPv6 addresses, associated with the interfaces.{{??}}`IPv6` route is added for IPv6 address, associated with the interface.{{?}} Due to a known bug in the `kernel`, when `ip6_route_dev_notify` function receives a **NULL** pointer from `snmp6_alloc_dev` while unregistering the network device, kernel panic occurs. The `snmp6_alloc_dev` returns **NULL** when CPU allocation fails. The following IPv6 enabled {{?Object.keys(pydata.ipv6_dev_routes).length>1}}interfaces are{{??}}interface is{{?}} present on this host: {{ for (var key in pydata.ipv6_dev_routes) { }} {{ } }}
Interface IPv6 Address
{{=key}} {{=pydata.ipv6_dev_routes[key]}}
data.more_info: For guidance on upgrading the kernel to a specific version, please refer to [How do I upgrade the kernel to a particular version manually?](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/161803)

data.description: Network connections will hang when insufficient memory is allocated for the TCP packet fragmentation
data.summary: Due to a known bug in kernel, network connections hang when insufficient memory is allocated for the TCP packet fragmentation.
data.generic: Due to a known bug in the `kernel`, TCP **Send-Q** or **TcpExtTCPWqueueTooBig** increases when skb split exceeds the allowed SNMP counter and kernel limits the memory allocation for the packet fragmentations, leading to network connections hangs.
data.reason: This host is running **kernel-{{=pydata.kernel}}** and insufficient memory is allocated for the TCP packet fragmentation `net.ipv4.tcp_wmem == {{=pydata.tcp_wmem[0]}} {{=pydata.tcp_wmem[1]}} {{=pydata.tcp_wmem[2]}}`. Due to a known bug in the `kernel`, TCP **Send-Q** or **TcpExtTCPWqueueTooBig** increases when skb split exceeds the allowed SNMP counter and kernel limits the memory allocation for the packet fragmentations. As a result, network connections will hang.
data.more_info: For guidance on upgrading the kernel to a specific version, please refer to [How do I upgrade the kernel to a particular version manually?](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/161803)

data.description: Unexpected synchronization of time occurs when NTP time sources contain leap-smearing servers with standard NTP servers
data.summary: When NTP configuration is not compatible with a server leap smear, unexpected correction of time or failed synchronization of time will occur during a leap smear.
data.generic: When NTP time sources contain leap-smearing servers with standard NTP servers, unexpected correction of time or failed synchronization of time will occur during a leap smear.

data.description: Other Linux release detected
data.summary: Third party components, or installation of a distribution that is not Red Hat Enterprise Linux can lead to difficulties in supporting your system.
data.generic:
The host appears to be running a version of Linux other than Red Hat Enterprise Linux, or has components from a third party distribution, in some circumstances, this can mean a support case will be rejected.

You should confirm that this machine is installed with RHEL and review the [Production Support Scope of Coverage](https://access.redhat.com/support/offerings/production/soc).
data.more_info: For more information about the Convert2RHEL utility, refer to the [An Introduction to Convert2RHEL](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/introduction-convert2rhel-now-officially-supported-convert-rhel-systems-rhel) blog.

resolution_set.resolution:
Another version of Linux installed or running on the container can present difficulties when investigating issues with Red Hat Global Support Services.

Depending on the situation, GSS may require you to demonstrate the problem on a RHEL only system or be unable to assist and reject your case in accordance with the [Production Support Scope of Coverage](https://access.redhat.com/support/offerings/production/soc).

data.description: Memory overcommit occurred due to memory overcommit policy
data.summary: Memory overcommit occurred due to memory overcommit policy.
data.generic: System stability will be compromised under memory intensive operations when **vm.overcommit_memory = 2** and **vm.overcommit_ratio = 100**
data.reason: Red Hat detected that there was kernal panic occurring in your system. And this host has been identified as having **vm.overcommit_memory = 2** AND **vm.overcommit_ratio = 100**,  which will impact the system's stability during memory-intensive periods.
data.more_info: For recommendations and available settings see [Red Hat Enterprise Linux Performance Tuning Guide - Capacity tuning](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/6/html/Performance_Tuning_Guide/s-memory-captun.html).

resolution_set.resolution:
Red Hat recommends that you set the `vm.overcommit_ratio` smaller than **100** to reduce the chances of the system being in this scenario.
1. Set `vm.overcommit_ratio` in `/etc/sysctl.conf`.
  ~~~
  vm.overcommit_ratio = [a value smaller than 100]
  ~~~
1. Execute the following command to make it effective.
  ~~~
  # sysctl -p
  ~~~

data.description: Installation of packages across major releases is not supported
data.summary: Installation of packages across major releases is not supported by Red Hat.
data.generic: Installation of RHEL X packages on RHEL Y systems (where X â‰  Y) is not supported by Red Hat.

resolution_set.resolution:
Red Hat recommends that you complete the following steps:
1. Remove the following {{?Object.keys(pydata.packages).length>1}}packages{{??}}package{{?}}:
  ~~~
  # yum remove{{~pydata.packages: e}} {{=e}}{{~}}
  ~~~
1. If necessary, install the related variants for the {{?Object.keys(pydata.packages).length>1}}packages{{??}}package{{?}} in above **RHEL{{=pydata.rhel}}**.

data.description: Red Hat has discontinued technical support services as well as software maintenance services for the End-Of-Life Ansible Engine
data.summary: When a product reaches End-Of-Life (EOL), Red Hat will discontinue technical support services as well as software maintenance services.
data.generic: This Ansible Engine has exceeded its End-of-Life. Red Hat has discontinued technical support services as well as software maintenance services for it.
data.more_info:
For more information regarding Red Hat product life cycles, refer to:
- [Life Cycle and Update Policies](https://access.redhat.com/support/policy/update_policies).
- [Product Life Cycles](https://access.redhat.com/product-life-cycles).

data.summary: When a product reaches End-Of-Life (EOL), Red Hat will discontinue technical support services as well as software maintenance services.
data.generic: This Red Hat Enterprise Linux has exceeded its End-of-Life. Red Hat has discontinued technical support services as well as software maintenance services for it.
data.more_info:

data.description: Decreased security: altered RPM packages
data.summary: The output of the `rpm -V` command on specific packages indicates that some installed files have been modified. These modifications can indicate that the file size, MD5sum, and the timestamp differ from what is expected, which can be a possible indication of malicious tampering of the system.
data.generic: The output of the `rpm -V` command on specific packages indicates that some installed files have been modified. These modifications can indicate that the file size, MD5sum, and the timestamp differ from what is expected, which can be a possible indication of malicious tampering of the system.
data.more_info:
* [How do I verify if some binary files installed via rpm in RHEL have been replaced?](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/1544003)
* [How to reinstall files reported by rpm -V to be missing or corrupted](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/183083)
* [Verifying packages](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/6/html/deployment_guide/s2-rpm-verifying)

resolution_set.resolution:
Red Hat recommends that you take one or more of the following actions:


* Determine whether your administrative procedures for the system involve modifying the listed files without using the `rpm` package manager.


* Reinstall the related package. To reinstall all packages checked by this Insights Recommendation:

   ~~~
   # yum reinstall coreutils procps procps-ng shadow-utils passwd sudo chrony
   ~~~

   **Please note** that this will destroy evidence if the system state is caused by unauthorized actions.


* Determine whether storage is operating correctly.

    * [What is smartd and how do I use it?](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/1456)
    * [How can I test if my hard disk is going bad?](https://access.redhat.com/articles/7703)
    * [Checking and repairing a file system](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/8/html/managing_file_systems/checking-and-repairing-a-file-system_managing-file-systems)


* Determine whether system memory (RAM) and the system hardware are operating correctly.

    * [How to install and enable rasdaemon](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/3742591)
    * [Checking for Hardware Errors](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/7/html/system_administrators_guide/ch-system_monitoring_tools#sec-Checking_for_Hardware_Errors)
    * [What information can be obtained from rasdaemon?](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/3742611)
    * [How to check if system RAM is faulty in Red Hat Enterprise Linux?](https://access.redhat.com/solutions/15693)


* Contact Red Hat Support Services for further assistance with this matter.

data.description: SAP instances failure occur when the values for some resource limits are below the SAP recommended values
data.summary: SAP applications require certain file handler or process resource in order to keep the application running properly. When resource limits do not meet SAP requirements, the SAP application will fail to run or its performance will degrade.
data.generic: SAP applications require certain file handler or process resource in order to keep the application running properly. When resource limits are below the SAP recommendations, the SAP instances will fail to run.
data.more_info:
For more information about configuring process resource limits for SAP instances, refer to the following SAP Note:
* [1771258 - Linux: User and system resource limits](https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/1771258)

data.description: SAP will not work well when missing required packages or the version of specific packages does not meet the minimal requirements
data.summary: The related functions of SAP applications do not work well because there is a lack of required packages or the version of specific packages does not meet the minimal requirements.
data.generic: The related functions of SAP applications do not work well because there is a lack of required packages or the version of specific packages does not meet the minimal requirements.
